image.alt_text: Photo by MG Stephens on December 20, 2020. May be an image of text that says 'GEORGIA, DENYING RECOGNITION TO NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES IS MODERN GENOCIDE (and let's talk about the toxic mining project you're building on sacred and spiritual cherokee triba sites)'.
image.caption:
from @erica.abke 💔 You cannot have a conversation about reparations without talking about Native Americans. 

Georgia, you are on stolen lands of the great Cherokee Nation, whom you forcibly removed with white supremacists’ autocratic policies. 

The #TrailofTears is a horrific recent event and not “just something that happened some time ago.” 

Why is the state of Georgia refusing federal recognition to the Tribes STILL today, if its’ government claims it is “not racist”? 
There are ZERO federally recognized Tribes in Georgia today. 

Reparations, which will be perceived as “inconvenient” to white Georgians, are past due. 

To suggest the Trail of Tears is in the past is a self-fulfilling white lie. The Trail of Tears effects are felt clearly  today by the Cherokee Nation, who are RIGHT NOW oppressed under the weight of institutionalized systemic racism. 

Are you aware of Georgia’s toxic Titanium Mine just outside the fragile Okefenokee Swamp, threatening the very existence of the sacred and spiritual sites of the Cherokee Nation, as well as the largest black water wetland in North America? Half a million acres of wildlife and ecosystems, at least. 

I spoke with Jane Winkler, a Tribal volunteer who is on the frontlines protecting ancestral lands and wildlife right up to the boundary of the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge. 

The mine site is at the head waters of the St. Mary River, and the National Seashore is at its’ end on the Intercoastal Waterway.

With the mine’s proximity to the headwaters of the Suwanee River, the NATIONWIDE environmental impact will be from the Atlantic all the way to the Gulf of Mexico. 

Efforts are ongoing. Learn more and support the work at www.protectOkefenokee.org

Comment if you think Georgia needs to close this mine for good and grant federal recognition WITH reparations to the Tribes.

image.alt_text: Photo by Jennifer Scanlan on March 08, 2021.
image.caption:
Continuing my #womenshistorymonth focus on #womenartists, this week I’m looking at women and text. Today I’m highlighting text in the work of Eastern Band Cherokee contemporary artist Shan Goshorn, from her recent retrospective at the Gilcrease Museum in Tulsa. 
.
.
.
While Goshorn worked in many media, she became best known for her baskets with Cherokee designs woven from documents that reflect the history of Indigenous people. 
.
.
.
1) The Stroke of a Pen, 2016, was woven from 3 documents that represent aspects of Goshorn’s history: a syllabary by Sequoyah, who designed the Cherokee written language; a Cherokee man’s description of what it is like to grow up and be Cherokee; and Goshorn’s grandmother’s memoires of her boarding school experience. 
.
.
.
2) Forever Woven into Our Fabric, 2012 lists the names of Carlisle Indian Boarding School students. The school’s curriculum was organized around the premise ‘Kill the Indian, Save the Man.’
.
.
.
3) Sealed Fate: Treaty of New Echota Protest Basket includes a controversial treaty signed by a minority of Cherokees which ceded their land to the US government, leading to the forced March to Oklahoma called ‘The Trail of Tears,’ a 95-page document with signatures of Cherokees protesting the treaty, and the top is a pattern called ‘Man-in-a-Coffin’ made from President Andrew Jackson’s signature, signifying his instrumental role in the violent and deadly removal..
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Carolina Trekker™ on June 15, 2021. May be an image of mountain, nature, sky, tree and twilight.
image.caption:
I try to stay away from filters and too much editing, but dialing in a few adjustments in @lightroom really added some drama to this one. Let’s also not forget that Great Smoky Mountains National Park was established on June 15, 1934... 100 years after the Indian Removal Act (May 28, 1830) forced the Cherokee out of their homes and off their lands, even if it meant killing children, women, the aged — and anyone else who defied this edict to resettle. The land that was left behind was logged, settled, and developed. Today visitors can see evidence of past progress and encroachment in the park — but the still fresh trail of Cherokee blood leading away from these mountains remains conveniently ignored...

•
•
•

image.alt_text: Photo by Visit Cherokee Nation in Brown's Ferry Tavern. May be an image of outdoors, tree and text that says 'kTPV4 DhGW Trail Tears National Historic Trail Brown's Ferry Tavern BROWNS TAVERN'.
image.caption:
Brown’s Ferry Tavern – the oldest standing structure in Chattanooga, Tenn. – was built in 1803, before the city was even founded. Cherokee businessman John Brown operated the tavern until he was removed to Indian Territory. It is said that John Ross married his first wife, Quatie, at the tavern; the landmark was also a stopping point for many Cherokees along the Trail of Tears in 1838. As the site of the 1863 Civil War Battle of Brown’s Ferry, the tavern and land were recently purchased by the American Battlefield Trust for preservation. #ThrowbackThursday

Image courtesy of the National Park Service.

image.alt_text: Photo by Wayne Garner in Austin, Texas.
image.caption: 190 years ago, U.S. Democratic President Andrew Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act into law. The Act authorized Jackson to grant unsettled lands west of the Mississippi River in exchange for tribal lands in the east. Few tribes went peacefully and many, including the Cherokee, resisted removal. From 1838 to 1839, the Cherokee were forcefully removed and nearly 4,000 died on what is now known as the Trail of Tears. #native #nativeamerican #cherokee #tsalagi #keetowah #trailoftears #americanindian #removalact #tribe

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Derek Lipscomb on February 24, 2021 tagging @rootsrugbyfamily, and @blackpowerinitiative. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, people sitting and indoor.
image.caption:
A large part of the #NewCivilRightsMovement has to do with #education, or rather the #miseducation of our students in all aspects of our schooling. Auditing and examining our schools’ curriculums would be a large first step to shining some light on how #InstitutionalRacism can be baked into a child’s experience. What books are they reading? How are they discussing #CurrentEvents? What kind of posters are going up in the classroom? What is the teachers’ experience with different cultural perspectives? All of these and more should be conversation schools have with themselves but also for parents to feel comfortable inquiring about. This dialogue will not only expand the scope and sequence of a school’s curriculum but it will allow there to be growth. Many students know #MartinLutherKingJr & #RosaParks but what about #MedgarEvers, #JamesBaldwin, #FannieLouHamer? Better yet, do they understand why those figures needed to exist in the first place? What were they fighting against? Who was the other side? It is important for students to explore these concepts early so they are able to navigate difficult racial conversations later and have the stamina for #CivilDiscourse.
.
Just like with #CriticalRaceTheory, reworking an entire school curriculum to embed #Diversity, #Equity, and #Inclusion work threatens the current power dynamic and racial hierarchy. It requires training teachers, parents, administrators, as well as board members. This relearning is uncomfortable partially because it requires a good school community culture to fully embrace this transition and many schools are held together with niceties and pseudo-genial relationships. DEI work requires a vulnerability unforeseen in a professional space and that can potentially fracture many schools that have based their education on whitewashing American history and its conflicts. I am not advocating for teaching children about the horrors of the #SlaveTrade, #TrailOfTears, #Lynching and the like, but rather speaking of the fragile situations Americans had to navigate to get where we are today. If we want our students to get through school with a healthy sense of identity, where else to start other than school?

The Trail of Tears was part of the Indian removal, a series of forced displacements and ethnic cleansing of approximately 60,000 Native Americans of the Five Civilized Tribes between 1830 and 1850 by the United States government. The affected nations were the Cherokee, Creek, Chickasaw, Choctaw, and Seminole #alwaysremeber #neverforget #valleyreb #smokingrabbit #cherokee #trailoftears ##creeknation #chickasaw #choctaw #familyhistory #familyhistorymatters #nativeamericans #nativeamericanhistory #americanhistory #americanindian #attrocities #firstnations #indigenousrights #indigenouspeople #indigenousamerican #nativeamericanrights

image.alt_text: Photo by Jenn Corleone in Fairfield, California. May be an image of seedlings and outdoors.
image.caption:
.
These seeds, their value, is in the memories they carry...
.
Cherokee Trail of Tears Beans.
.
In 1819, the US Government recognized the Cherokee Nation as sovereign, and signed a treaty guaranteeing the removal of any present and future White intruders.
.
In 1825, The Cherokee Nation, located in the Appalachian Mountains, established their capital in New Echota, Georgia, where they built a newspaper among other businesses and even built a courthouse.  Despite the White man’s assault on their land, they managed to thrive anyway.
.
Then, with the election of Andrew Jackson in 1829, everything changed.  Jackson believed the Cherokee people to be savages.  In 1830, The People of The Cherokee Nation were violently, forcibly removed from their homes.  Many were shackled.  They were forced to then walk more than 1,000 miles to Oklahoma.  More than 1/3 died along the way...nearly 20,000 people.
.
This is why the path they took is called The Trail Of Tears.
.
These people could only take what they could carry.  These beans were precious enough to them to grab as they were being masacred and forcibly relocated.  I have been waiting for the right conditions to grow them.  It is time.
.
Let’s stop repeating history, shall we?!
.
Peace, Y’All.
👩🏻‍🌾✌🏽🖤
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Lakota People's Law Project on February 19, 2021.
image.caption:
Posted @withregram • @_natv .
Reservation Mathematics: Navigating Love in Native America by Tailyr Irvine
.
Reservation Mathematics: Navigating Love in Native America explores the complex issue of measuring “Indian blood” and how it relates to dating in Native America. Blood quantum restrictions leave a limited pool of potential partners for tribal members looking to continue tribal bloodlines. Measuring Native blood is an unsustainable, colonial system placed on the shoulders of single Natives who are trying to find a partner in a shrinking pool or who might feel directly responsible for the complete genocide of Native people. If their children do not meet the minimum quantum, they’re not considered a member of the tribe—regardless if the mother or father is enrolled. In her project, Tailyr questions what makes someone Native. Is it quantum, culture, or a combination of both? 
.
Tailyr Irvine is a photojournalist from the Flathead Reservation in Montana. Her work focuses on challenging stereotypical narratives with photos that provide deeper representation of the lives and the complex issues within the diverse communities that make up Native America. Tailyr worked at the Dallas Morning News and Tampa Bay Times before beginning her career as an independent journalist.
.
Check out her work: WWW.TAILYRIRVINE.COM •  @TAILYRIRVINE
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Ryan T Dalgliesh in Norman, Oklahoma. May be an illustration.
image.caption:
AVAILABLE: Wolf Robe was born between 1838 and 1841. He died in 1910 in Oklahoma. When he was about thirty years old he was forced off his land and relocated his tribe to the Cheyenne and Arapaho Indian Reservation. The history of the various Indian tribes is rich and deeply sad. I’ve recommended before, and do here again, that you read the books “Bury My Heart At Wounded Knee” and “Black Elk Speaks”. They will break your heart and open your eyes to some things you likely didn’t know. I’m all for expanding my base of knowledge and am working to be a voracious reader/learner in the second half of my life. This painting is available for immediate purchase. I think of it not as a caricature but as a legacy and historical reminder. I adore painting these pieces and absorbing the history associated with them. #rtdalglieshfineart 
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Welcome Native Store on April 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
DID YOU KNOW ABOUT THE TRAIL OF TEARS?
🔥 By 1838, only about 2,000 Cherokees had left their Georgia homeland for Indian Territory. Cherokee into stockades at bayonet point while whites looted their homes and belongings. Then, they marched the Indians more than 1,200 miles to Indian Territory. Whooping cough, typhus, dysentery, cholera and starvation were epidemic along the way, and historians estimate that more than 5,000 Cherokee died as a result of the journey.
💥 By 1840, tens of thousands of Native Americans had been driven off of their land in the southeastern states and forced to move across the Mississippi to Indian Territory. The federal government promised that their new land would remain unmolested forever, but as the line of white settlement pushed westward, “Indian Country” shrank and shrank. In 1907, Oklahoma became a state and Indian Territory was gone for good.
🍀 We are very proud to be Cherokee Indian. 🌻🌻Are you proud of the Cherokee people?

image.alt_text: Photo by Miłosz Lucyna in Pelplin gmina with @altrarunning, @m_trail_runner, @lucynanalborska, @altrarunning_europe, @altrarunningpl, @mam_na_to_wybiegane, and @altrarunningfans. May be an image of one or more people, tree and outdoors.
image.caption:
Jak to jest że gdy patrzymy przez okno to nawet wyjść się z domu nie chce. Mózg generuje takie wymówki że głowa mała 😂. I tak będzie do samej wiosny 😉 trzeba będzie się motywować na maxa aby zrobić trening. Jedynie w naszej rodzinie to Wicher nie potrzebuje żadnej motywacji ,on jak tylko usłyszy że otwieramy szafę i bierzemy ciuchy cieszy się niesamowicie a jak usłyszy piknięcie zegarka to leci jak dzik w szyszki 🤦. Musimy nauczyć się takiej motywacji 😊. 
Dziś kolejny dzień trailu ,15km w nóżkach zostało a po wczorajszych podbiegach nogi trochę czuły ale co nas nie zabije to nas wzmocni. 
Życzymy wszystkim ogromu motywacji i aby była z wami zawsze 😊

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Jan ⚜️ on May 16, 2021 tagging @earthpix, @ipulledoverforthis, @fingerprintofgod, @discoveroklahoma, @waterfallsfordays, @onlyinoklahoma, @oklahomastateparks, @waterfalls_collective, @lensloves_nature, and @total_waterfalls. May be an image of waterfall, tree and nature.
image.caption:
The park has quite a history, dating back to the 1830s when the region was designated as the Cherokee Nation during the Indian Removal Act of 1830 (also known as the Trail of Tears, when the Cherokee were forced to relocate to the west). When the Civil War started, the tribe became divided and non-Indians began moving into the area illegally. In fact, this section of the Ozarks was a known hideout for bands of outlaws that raided the area and those traveling through it. The activities in the area are thought to have been the inspiration for movies such as True Grit and Hang ‘Em High .
The lawless Old West days ended when “Hanging Judge” Isaac C. Parker and his Deputy U.S. Marshals from Fort Smith, Arkansas came to the area in the 1870s. He worked with the Cherokee Nation to bring order to the region, and earned his “Hanging Judge” nickname from the large number of outlaws he convicted and sentenced to death.
In the 1900s, the park was privately owned and operated as a tourist attraction, and in 1974, was the site of the American film classic, Where the Red Fern Grows. During this time, the waterfall was known as Dripping Springs Falls, but was renamed Natural Falls to distinguish it from another state park in Oklahoma also called Dripping Springs State Park.
-Backwoods/Doug Wertman
(@sheira_snyder my niece & road tripper)

image.alt_text: Photo by Georgia State Parks in New Echota State Historic Site. May be an image of outdoors and tree.
image.caption:
Today was a dark day in #Cherokee history. On September 15, 1831, the Trail of Tears began. Learn more from @newechotahistoricsite, then plan to visit soon. New Echota is in Calhoun, and you'll see numerous original and reconstructed buildings, plus a museum and nature trail. The gift shop is filled with fascinating books as well.

image.alt_text: Photo by MrWissen2go Geschichte in Flathead Indian Reservation. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text.
image.caption:
Dieses Foto sieht nicht nach einem gelungenen Treffen aus. Rund um den Mann mit schickem Anzug und Hut gucken viele eher gequält in die Kamera. Dabei ist hoher Besuch da: An diesem Tag 1907 besucht der US-amerikanische Innenminister James Rudolph Garfield das Reservat der Salish- und Kootenai-Stämme in Montana.⁣
⁣
Die Familien der Menschen, die sich um den Politiker reihen, stammen ursprünglich nicht aus #Montana. Einst hat der Stamm der #Salish im Nordwesten seine Heimat: Das Territorium umspannt ein Gebiet zwischen den oberen Ausläufern der Flüsse Clark Fork und Columbia und der Bitterroot Range, also einem Teil der Rocky Mountains. Doch wie viele andere Stämme indigener Ureinwohner stehen sie den Interessen der europäischen Siedler im Wege. 1855 unterschreiben Vertreter verschiedener Stämme einen Vertrag mit dem Gouverneur des Washingtoner Territoriums. Darin treten sie ihr Gebiet an den Staat ab. Dafür wird ihnen ein Gebiet auf der anderen Seite der Rockies zugewiesen; genannt Flathead, oder Jocko, in Montana. Doch auch dort können sie nicht lange bleiben. Anfang des 20. Jahrhunderts zwingt die US-Regierung Landbesitzer im #Reservat, Teile ihres Lands an weiße #Siedler zu verkaufen. Und sie zweigt sich Land für eigene Zwecke ab. Zwischen 1904 und 1908 verlieren die Indigenen so ein Drittel des Reservats. Und damit oftmals ihre Lebensgrundlage: Denn seit der Ankunft der Weißen sind die Salish #Pferdezüchter. Große Herden bestehen aus 3.000 Tieren – die haben in dem eng begrenzten Land keinen Platz mehr. Kein Wunder also, das die Stimmung bei dem Treffen mit Innenminister Garfield 1907 mehr als getrübt ist.⁣
⁣
Heutzutage ist das Flathead-Reservat das viertgrößte in den #USA. Dort lebt ein Großteil der 7.500 Stammesmitglieder der Salish. Mehr zum Schicksal der Indigenen erfahrt Ihr in unserem neuen Video.⁣
Was haltet Ihr von solchen Reservaten für Indigene?⁣
© Getty / Education Images / Kontributor⁣
⁣

image.alt_text: Photo shared by MulticulturalChildrensBookDay on January 25, 2020 tagging @tahlequahtdp.
image.caption:
Cherokee author and art teacher releases children’s book on the Trail of Tears. Andrea L. Rogers, a citizen of the Cherokee Nation, has announced the release of her new children’s book on the Trail of Tears. "Mary and the Trail of Tears: A Cherokee Removal Survival Story" is part of The Girls Survive historical fiction series for ages 8-12 published by Stone Arch Books, a Capstone imprint.

Twelve-year-old Mary and her Cherokee family are forced out of their home in Georgia by U.S. soldiers in May 1838. From the beginning of the forced move, Mary and her family are separated from her father. Facing horrors such as internment, violence, disease, and harsh weather, Mary perseveres and helps keep her family and friends together until they can reach the new Cherokee Nation in Indian Territory. image.alt_text: Photo by Stéphanie Mesnier auteur on December 15, 2019.
image.caption:
Le 15 décembre 1890, le chef sioux Sitting Bull (Tȟatȟáŋka Íyotake), figure importante de la résistance amérindienne, quittait ce monde pour partir vers des terrains de chasse éternels. 
Son message résonne étrangement aujourd'hui :
"Voyez Mes frères, le printemps est venu ; la terre a reçu l'étreinte du soleil, et nous verrons bientôt les fruits de cet amour! Chaque graine s'éveille et de même chaque animal prend vie. C'est à ce mystérieux pouvoir que nous devons nous aussi notre existence ; c'est pourquoi nous concédons à nos voisins, même à nos voisins animaux, le même droit qu'à nous d'habiter cette terre. Pourtant, écoutez-moi, vous tous, nous avons maintenant affaire à une autre race, petite faible quand nos pères l'on rencontrée pour la première fois, mais aujourd'hui grande et arrogante. Assez étrangement, ils ont dans l'idée de cultiver le sol et l'amour de posséder est chez eux une maladie. Ces gens-là ont établi beaucoup de règles que les riches peuvent briser mais non les pauvres. Ils prélèvent des taxes sur les pauvres et les faibles pour entretenir les riches qui gouvernent. Ils revendiquent notre mère à tous, la terre, pour leur propre usage et se barricadent contre leurs voisins ; ils la défigurent avec leurs constructions et leurs ordures. Cette nation est pareille à un torrent de neige fondue qui sort de son lit et détruit tout sur son passage. Nous ne pouvons vivre côte à côte".
#sittingbull #natives #sioux #tȟatȟáŋkaíyotake #indianchief #usa #ernielapointe #nativeamerican #nativeamericans #lakota #dakota #trailoftears #sittingbullhislifehislegacy #memory #indigenous #heritage #chaman #indiens #hunkpapalakota

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Orna Ross on May 13, 2020 tagging @choctawnationok, and @irish1nterest. May be an image of outdoors.
image.caption:
Today’s #poem is “Feathers of Steel.” •

Behold these feathers of steel. 
The ‘Kindred Spirits’ monument 
in County Cork, Ireland,
commemorates a kindness.
In 1847 the Choctaw people,
expelled from their lands
to a trail of tears 
and disease,
still found a way to donate 
hundreds of pounds sterling
(what would be thousands today) 
to a relief fund for the Irish 
then enduring starvation 
from an inflicted famine
•
A century and three-quarters on
the Choctaw fighting for life 
against a virus stalking
their Oklahoma reservation 
find the Irish remember, 
quote the long dead benefactors 
as they now donate to this cause 
in extraordinary number •
Two peoples bound 
by knowing how it feels
to have your land and your ways, 
your food and your tongue taken
by force
and the grace 
of good given
compassion reaching 
across the world’s 
second-widest ocean
across oceans of distinction
and time. Behold 
these feathers of steel. •
•
•
#kindredspirits #corkireland #choctaw #irishfamine #trailoftears

image.caption: On October 24th 1838 a detachment of 858 Cherokee encamped along the Red River at Port Royal TN on their journey to reservations in Oklahoma. Having been forcibly removed from their ancestral homelands, many suffered from exposure, disease and starvation. Elijah Hicks, the leader of the expedition wrote,”…tell our friends that we are on the journey west, arising from the acts of wicked men and from our unfortunate fate.” This fateful trek is called “The Trail of Tears “ // #viewpoint #tnhistory #trailoftears #portroyaltn #outdoors #outdoorphotography #trails #hikeinthewoods #tennessee #middletn

image.alt_text: Photo by Scenic City Sights in Ross's Landing. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.
image.caption:
What stands today as a fun spot for the children to frolick about in the artistically designed stair fountains also has an important story and history.
⋆ ⋆ ⋆
"Ross's Landing in Chattanooga, Tennessee, is the last site of the Cherokee's 61-year occupation of Chattanooga and is considered to be the embarkation point of the Cherokee removal on the Trail of Tears. Ross's Landing Riverfront Park memorializes the location, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places."

The landing was named for John Ross, later principal chief of the Cherokee Nation. In 1816 Ross settled at the site along the Tennessee River above Chattanooga Creek. There he established a trading post on the northern border of the Cherokee Nation, across the river from the United States of America. This area became known as "Ross's Warehouse," and "Ross's Ferry" (and alternatively, "Ross's Landing"). It was known to those passing through the area to have the best conditions for a river flatboat crossing. Ross operated a swing ferry across the river that was anchored on McClellan Island."
- Wikipedia

image.alt_text: Photo by Visit Cherokee Nation in John Ross Museum. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
On this day in 1790, John Ross was born in Turkey Town, Alabama, along the Coosa River in the northeast corner of the state. He led the Cherokee Nation from 1828 to 1866, spanning the tumultuous years of his tribe’s removal from the Cherokees’ eastern homelands to Indian Territory. Remembered for his unflinching fight against the U.S. government to prevent removal, Ross died while in office on Aug. 1, 1866, in Washington, DC.

Visit to the John Ross Museum in Park Hill, Okla. to learn the story of John Ross.

Image courtesy of the Library of Congress.

image.alt_text: Photo by ANDREW  G  IMAGE©️ in National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum with @travelok, @nationalcowboymuseum, @polarpro, @visitokc, @bedfordcamera, @smithsoniannmai, @raw_community, @andrew_g_image, @visitcherokeenation, @405mag, @bedfordsokc, @onlyinoklahoma, @raw_community_member, @okcommerce, @thisisoklahoma, @thecherokeenation, and @photocon_okc. May be a black-and-white image of indoor.
image.caption:
_
I N T O  T H E  P A C I F I C
“End of the Trail” is a sculpture by James Earle Fraser. This picture was taken Monday evening at the @nationalcowboymuseum which is home to the original sculpture created by Fraser. 
I was privileged to attend the @oksportshof 2020 Induction Ceremony (postponed due to COVID-19).
•
M Y  F A M I L Y
•
I am blessed to be married to a Native American woman, a member of @thecherokeenation to be exact. Therefore, our children are also members of the Cherokee Tribe. My wife’s ancestors came to this state by the most intense & dire of circumstances from Georgia, part of the 13,000 Cherokee forced from their ancestral lands into Cleveland, Tennessee, which served as a virtual holding pin for all Cherokee being forcibly pressed from Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, & Alabama by an armed militia of 7,000.
Once all the Cherokee were in one large group in Tennessee, they were then forced to begin a brutal journey spanning over 1,000 miles, most on barefoot, during one of the harshest winters...the winter of 1938. Thousands of Cherokees died on that reckless trek.
•
F O R C E D
•
My shortened & paraphrased version of the Cherokee Nation forced into taking the ill-fated journey from their southern homelands to Oklahoma (Indian Territory) is only one small part of the much larger history recounting the forced relocation of many tribes & black slaves around that same time. They were forced. It was a time of great suffering & sadness.
It’s this season of brutality & forced relocation that inspired the sculpture pictured in this post.
•
S C U L P T U R E
•
Fraser first modeled the subject in 1894. He based it on his experience as a boy in the Dakota Territory. His memoirs state, "as a boy, I remembered an old Dakota trapper saying, 'The Indians will someday be pushed into the Pacific Ocean.'" Later he stated "the idea occurred to me of making an Indian which represented his race reaching the end of the trail, at the edge of the Pacific."
•
#mmiwawareness2021 #mmiwawareness

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Mathangi Subramanian on July 21, 2020 tagging @noblemaillard. May be an image of child and book.
image.caption:
We've just moved to #Denver, which is the unceded, ancestral territory of the Sioux, Cheyenne, Arapahoe, and Ute people. (At least that's what my research says - if you know better, please tell me in the comments!) So it seems fitting that our first new #picturebook here is #Frybread, a brilliant celebration of this delicious Native food. The text is a list poem that describes fry bread as sound, taste, time, and memory, and it's made kiddo and I think about the foods our family cherishes, and how these recipes came to be. The gorgeous illustrations show people of a variety of skin tones and hair textures, all of whom are implied to be Native. Mentions of the #TrailOfTears is beautifully balanced with images of joy, and the end notes go into the history of how fry bread was developed. Highly recommend this one, and kiddo does too. (Image description: the book Fry Bread on a red background.)
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Welcome Native Store on December 15, 2020 tagging @native_culture_pride. May be an image of nature.
image.caption:
Keep your head up. Keep dancing. Nothing can take you down.💃💃💃
⭐The Fancy Shawl dance is one of the most athletic dance styles. It is also the most recent, created to allow Native American women to express the same enthusiasm and show-style as the men’s Fancy Dance. The dance has two main steps: a regular dance, and a crow hop. Often times, steps are repeated in sequences of four, to represent the four directions and balance. 
🔥The second step, the crow hop, is an imitation of the way a crow moves across the ground.
The dance is said to imitate the graceful, swooping beauty of a butterfly.🦋

image.alt_text: Photo by Visit Cherokee Nation on May 28, 2020. May be an image of one or more people.
image.caption:
On this day 190 years ago, U.S. President Andrew Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act into law. The Act authorized Jackson to grant unsettled lands west of the Mississippi River in exchange for tribal lands in the east. Few tribes went peacefully and many, including the Cherokee, resisted removal. From 1838 to 1839, the Cherokee were forcefully removed and nearly 4,000 died on what is now known as the Trail of Tears. 
Image courtesy of the National Portrait Gallery, Smithsonian Institution.
.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by JAIME CEPERO on October 12, 2020.
image.caption:
Today I honor and uplift my #Taino ancestors. Did you know that over 65% of Puertorican Peoples carry indigenous Taino or similarly tribal DNA? Our people ruled the Caribbean peacefully until the arrival of Columbus and his dogs in 1492. We ate fish, roots, plants and herbs. We wore shells and gold and crystals and feathers and we danced in ceremony. We had female rulers. We had many gods. We respected same sex relationships and honored two spirit peoples. We were described in colonizer journals as being “handsome bodied with pretty faces and open arms”. 

I believe our due karma from the genocide of those days is coming. It may well already be here. 

#happyindigenouspeoplesday #afrolatinx

Alsof Nice to see that,even in death,he still stands out of the crowd...A bright spot surrounded by black marble and Bluestone.
Mission accomplished.
Here's to love eternal.

image.alt_text: Photo by ANDREW  G  IMAGE©️ in National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum with @travelok, @nationalcowboymuseum, @polarpro, @visitokc, @bedfordcamera, @djiglobal, @raw_community, @andrew_g_image, @405mag, @bedfordsokc, @onlyinoklahoma, @oklahomalifestyle, @raw_community_member, @okcommerce, @thisisoklahoma, and @dronelahoma. May be an image of tree and outdoors.
image.caption:
_
A  W E S T E R N  H E R I T A G E
This is the backyard of the National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.
[ @nationalcowboymuseum ]
Growing up in Oklahoma City, this was always one of my favorite places to visit. Very early on, those visits impacted some little spaces of my life. However, those little spaces created wonder & intrigue. That intrigue has fueled a life-long quest to learn about Native American & American Western history, the heritage, culture, & landscape. I wore bolo ties to children’s church on Sundays & absolutely knew they were the coolest, even though every kid my age firmly disagreed.😄
As a preteen, I began borrowing my Grandpa’s audio tapes of artists such as Bob Wills, Eddy Arnold, Marty Robbins, Johnny Horton, Jimmy Dean, Spade Cooley, Lefty Frizzell, & my favorite music artist of all, Johnny Cash. “A Boy Named Sue” didn’t exactly pump my football teammates up for practice as they rode with me from the school to the field.
The western life, the Cowboy Way, & the endless possibilities that lie ahead a fella & his horse; these were themes on display that jumped out to a young suburban boy & sparked imagination.
I’ve returned to the museum regularly throughout my life, finding something new every visit. Fantastic events are held year round. The museum regularly hosts various exhibitions & art collections of international renown, not to mention the museum’s own premier collection of Western art & artifacts highlighting America’s Western history & culture.
There is so much to discover about this national treasure located right here in Oklahoma City.
•
I try to avoid my posts serving as a remote locale for “travel guide” style info. I’m not sponsored by the National Cowboy Museum or their affiliates. Their IG account doesn’t even follow mine. [ ouch ]😔
I post this info from the heart. I like this place, what they’ve done with it through the years, & all the history, culture, & art it mobilizes to be accessed by so many people of all ages, from all different places. Good stuff!
•
Enjoy!
•
•
#andrewgimage #HashtagTheCowboy

image.alt_text: Photo by Arts for Art in Paris with @littlehueymusic, and @festivalsonsdhiver. May be an image of 1 person and text.
image.caption:
UPDATE DATED 2/17/22: UPDATE: William Parker's concert at Sons d'hiver has been POSTPONED to Saturday, February 19, 2022. Please visit the Sons d'hiver Facebook page or sonsdhiver.org for more information.
***

We’re thrilled to be presenting William Parker’s “Trail of Tears Continuum 1492–2022” at the Sons D’hiver Festival in Paris on February 18th

The Trail Of Tears Continuum 1492–2022 is a tone poem that reflects the history, pain, and hope inspired by The #TrailOfTears —the devastating relocation of 100,000 indigenous people, including members of the Cherokee and Choctaw nations, forced from their lands that resulted in the death of over five thousand people. This performance, written and created by William Parker, uses original music, poetry, dance, and video to tell this story. Moving seamlessly from one style of music to another, Parker uses the concept of Universal Tonality jazz, opera, folk, all blended as one.

Join us if you’re in the neighborhood😉 Link in bio for more information and tickets.

image.caption:
"DEMONS BY ANOTHER NAME"
023.
In December of 1890, FIVE THOUSAND american troops descended upon a Lakota camp and massacered hundreds of Lakota people. nearly half of them were women and children.

“I can still see the butchered women and children lying heaped and scattered all along the crooked gulch as plain as when I saw them with eyes still young. And I can see that something else died there in the bloody mud, and was buried in the blizzard. A people’s dream died there.” -Black Elk
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Nina Yagual 🍉🦨🍒skunka de arte on June 16, 2021. May be an illustration.
image.caption:
Grapefruit came from Barbados, an island that my Black ancestors were temporarily ported on the way to a North or South Carolina slave port during the trans Atlantic slave trade. Where they were enslaved in West Virginia for some time before being forcibly removed with the Natives and then making the long walk on the trail of tears to Oklahoma, where my dads whole family was born. Black folks were enslaved by the Cherokees/creek/Choctaw on the trail of tears. They were forced to remove trail obstructions, take care of the young and elderly, protect the everyone from wild animals and bad weather. They would often forced to walk ahead while people rested to make sure the trail was safe. We disproportionately lost over half of our Black ancestors on the trail of tears. Someone had to survive for me to be here. Someone did it for me. I love grapefruits and I wonder if my ancestors had the chance to try them during their kidnapping through Barbados. Grapefruit is what I offer to them now, through my body and spirit.

.
.
.
.

.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Hands Free Mama on September 04, 2020 tagging @kaitlincurtice. May be an image of text that says 'If we can return to the essence of our identities, we can teach the children around US to know who they are at a young age-- & perhaps one day, when they create the future, they will work together to change things & heal systems we had no idea how to heal." -kaitlin b. curtice, NATIVE'.
image.caption:
@kaitlincurtice’s teachings allow us to recognize and acknowledge how colonization and the forced removal of Indigenous people from their homelands have left many disconnected from their identity, culture and spirituality. Today Kaitlin reminds us that The Potawatomi were forced from Indiana to Kansas on this day, September 4, 1838, on the Trail of Death.

In her book, Native, Kaitlin writes: "I feel deep within my bones what it means to be one who is removed, one who is assimilated, one whose people remain invisible. And yet, our stories will always carry us, because that is exactly what they are meant to do.”
.
.
She also writes: “If we can return to the essence of our identities, we can teach the children around us to know who they are from a young age, and perhaps one day, when they are older, when they create the future, they will work together to change things and to heal systems we had no idea how to heal.”
.
.
My friends, today offers us an opportunity to educate our children about the suffering on the Trail of Tears, an event in our nation’s history that has been erased and forgotten. By doing so, we prepare young people to better understand the reality of their peers’ lived experiences — and the history that informs those struggles.

Kaitlin recommends visiting https://native-land.ca. There, you can type in your zip code and find out what Indigenous groups lived in your area. A simple way to start centering Indigenous people is to acknowledge the original people of the land on which you are living, working, or traveling. In addition to that, I would like to emphasis the importance of making a conscious effort to listen and amplify Indigenous voices, as well as purchasing from Indigenous artists and creators.

Kaitlin’s recent bestseller, NATIVE, is necessary reading that offers us a way forward together.

My hand in yours
Rachel #amplifyindigenousvoices #nativebook #trailoftears #landacknowledgement #truthteller

image.alt_text: Photo by Visit Cherokee Nation on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.
image.caption:
Actor, playwright and author John Howard Payne arrived in Cherokee Nation in October 1835 looking for stories to write for publication. Introduced to Principal Chief John Ross, Payne was invited to learn more about the removal threat and attend the National Council at Red Clay in Tennessee where a possible treaty with the U.S. was discussed and rejected. Payne was Ross’ houseguest on Nov. 7, 1835, when the Georgia Guard came and arrested both men. They were taken and held for suspicion of planning an insurrection of Cherokees and slaves against Americans but later released. Payne wrote not only about the ordeal but against Cherokee removal. His contributions to the invaluable Payne-Butrick Papers offer unique insights into Cherokee traditional life. #ThrowbackThursday

Image courtesy of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

image.caption:
"DEMONS BY ANOTHER NAME"
027.
In 1948 George Gillette, Chairman of three affiliated tribes (Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara), wept as he watched A.J. King sign the Pick Sloan Flood Control Act. This act gave the federal govt. the greenlight to flood 156,000 acres of tribal land. Keep in mind that these tribes like all other were already FORCED to relocate to this reservation. This displaced around 300 families and 1700 residents and forced them to relocate AGAIN. The flooded land also wiped out their tribes hospital leaving them untreated and unhealthy. Clearly they did not willingly sign this act, they were under threat.
.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Phineas & Seamus on June 20, 2020. May be an image of text that says 'Chief Jawseph I will bite no more forever #SHARKSOFHISTORY'.
image.caption:
A brave, young Native American leader, Chief Jawseph, also known at Fin-mah-tooth-yah-lat-kekt, led his band of the Nez Perce tribe across the American Northwest to seek refuge in Canada (where Chief Swimming Bull had already found political asylum) so that they wouldn’t be forced to live on a reservation. He was pursued by the US Army, which was evicting all native tribes from their lands so that they could give the land to settlers. After fighting many battles and enduring hardship, Chief Jawseph surrendered to the army with the words, “From where the sun now stands, I will bite no more forever.” He was just 40 miles from the Canada border.
😢😢😢

image.alt_text: Photo by DENALI on September 07, 2021. May be an image of jeep and outdoors.
image.caption:
Cherokee Indians remained here, in the vast wilderness of their homeland, to avoid being forcibly moved by President Andrew Jackson to lands west of the Mississippi in the 1830s, a journey known as the Trail of Tears. The Cherokee had a word for this hiding place: Iyentooga, from which Heintooga took its name.

Although the land is now part of the national park, Richard Sneed, principal chief of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians, says the mountains protected and provided for his people for many years. “Our hearts are connected to this place,” he says. #trailoftears #cherokeenation #cherokee #northcarolina  #history #taketheroadlesstraveled #goingbackintime

image.caption:
Trail of Tears 2018, Benge Route. I had a lot of support, many skeptics, those sitting back betting on me to fail, and people who I never knew become close friends and some of my biggest fans 🙌🏽 

Don’t allow the critics and negative chatter keep you in a prison. Shut off the noise, focus on the task then execute. 

Why am I sharing this? YOU ARE NOT PROMISED TOMORROW! You better get busy living TODAY! 

When was the last time you took a chance? 

When was the last time you put yourself in a position where your chances of failing were greater than your chances at success? 

Let’s get it!

image.caption:
"DEMONS BY ANOTHER NAME"
028.
To my fellow Colorado natives, the Sand Creek Masaacre happened right in our backyard.
On November 29, 1864 hundreds of cavalrymen surrounded a camp of about 1000 Arapaho and Cheyenne. The Natives raised an American flag and white flags, the known sign of peace and surrender. The troops replied with gunfire and cannons. It was a mass murder. They massacred them, most of them being elders, women and children. The troops burned everything, mutilated the bodies and took body parts as trophies. This is genocide.
.
.

image.caption:
Charlene Teters (Spokane) is photographed in front of the border wall for her exhibit "Way of Sorrows."⁠
⁠
⁠
Teters says “From famine, disease, and empire, Native people have experienced forced migrations and marches. There have been many trails of tears and marches of death in this hemisphere since Columbus. The caravans coming to our southern border are part of an uninterrupted history of forced migrations and trails of tears.”⁠
⁠
⁠
We are currently closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but her exhibit is on display until May 17.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by ⫷KVRVK⫸ on October 24, 2020 tagging @downiewenjack.
image.caption:
"DEMONS BY ANOTHER NAME"
024.

 On October 22, 1966, a 12-year old Anishinaabe boy named Chanie Wenjack died trying to make his way back home to Ogoki Post from the American Indian Residential School in Kenora that he escaped from. To put that in perspective, a CHILD would rather put himself through a 600km/372m journey through the wilderness and freezing cold of Ontario than live under the conditions and atrocities of American Indian Residential school. This did not happen long ago AT ALL, for example in this same year NASA launched Lunar Orbiter 1 and the US v USSR space race was well underway. Today Chanie would only be 66 years old, this could have been any of our fathers, uncles, or grandfathers. He is still loved and missed by his family and community today. Rest In Power Chanie✊🏽🖤
.

image.alt_text: Photo shared by Laura 📍Oklahoma on July 07, 2020 tagging @seed_savers_exchange, and @greatlakesstapleseeds. May be an image of plant and outdoors.
image.caption:
Two First Nation brothers & three sisters!  The boys were home for the holiday and it was great to spend time with them.
.
Our Three Sisters planting features a Cherokee corn that can be used for popping, Cherokee Trail of Tears beans from Dr. Wyche of Oklahoma (these were carried by his ancestors over the Trail of Tears), and Algonquin pumpkins.
.
I am happy I finally grew some Three Sisters plantings as I had wanted to do it for years.  If you have kids it could be a great way to teach them about Native American/First Nation history (especially now that some folks will be learning from home more!). Even my “big” kids were interested to learn more about their heritage.
.

image.alt_text: Photo by Downtown Springfield on October 11, 2021. May be art.
image.caption:
Before John Polk Campbell and his brother carved their initials into an ash tree in 1829, several indigenous tribes made the land now known as Springfield their home from about the 1600s to the 1800s.
•
On #IndigenousPeoplesDay we honor the Osage tribe, the most dominant in the area, who used these lands for hunting and trading. The Osage set up camps here, then grew those camps into villages
•
We also honor the Delaware, Kickapoo, Shawnee and others who were relocated to the Ozarks from the East and made this land their temporary home.
•
We also remember all the lives lost on the Trail of Tears, which passed through our city. Historic markers in our neighborhood bring attention to segments of the trail’s original route.
•
Visit @historymuseumonthesquare to learn more about the people who first built their lives in Springfield. You can also see an original mural by Andy Thomas created especially for this gallery. It’s titled “The Trail of Tears through Springfield.” The @springfieldgreenecountylibrary also has educational resources.

image.caption: Choctaw hogs - Critically Endangered: In the 1830s when the Choctaw and other Native Americans were forced from the deep South to the Oklahoma Territory, they took their hogs with them. The last remnants of this population are still in southeastern Oklahoma. The Livestock Conservancy has established a conservation program to bring the breed back from the brink of extinction, but it should be noted that obtaining Choctaw hog breeding stock will likely not be available for at least another year or two. image.alt_text: Photo shared by 📚Just Cindy📚 on November 18, 2021 tagging @scholasticinc, @timtingle2, @bookiebuddie2, @rise_shine_booksta, @_hooked.on.books_, @bookstacommentsgroup, and @undercover_bookaddicts. May be an image of book and text that says 'Tim Tingle how became became a ghost Trailo Tears A Choctaw Story SCHOLASTIC SCHOLASTIC'.
image.caption:
Book Review

How I Became a Ghost
By Tim Tingle

In honor of Native American history month, my son and I read this one during our homeschooling lessons. There aren't many middle grade books about the Trail of Tears, so I don't have much to compare it to, but this one was pretty enthralling. It starts off with the main character proclaiming that he is a ghost, one that had only recently been a little boy...and then he tells you how it all happened. (It's NOT a ghost story...more of a tale of ancestors and departed souls watching over the living.)

Based on true experiences of the plight and suffering the Choctaw Indians faced during the Trail of Tears, it was a soulful and informative read for a child learning about one of our darkest times in American history. There is a lot of pain and anguish, which can be hard for some little ones to handle, but its realism and (sort of) happy ending made it worth the trouble.

image.caption:
#OnThisDay in 1836, #CherokeeNation Principal Chief John Ross presented Congress with a petition against removal signed by 15,665 Cherokee Nation citizens. The Senate did not act on the petition. Less than two years later, nearly all Cherokees were rounded up in preparation for forced removal to Indian Territory, a thousand miles west. The journey came to be known as the #TrailofTears

image.alt_text: Photo by Sharon Velez Diodonet 🇵🇷 in Bushwick with @bathandbodyworks, @travelling.the.pages, @timtingle2, @_indigathon, @pnwxbibliophile, @bookbfflikes, @book.dragons.united, @bookstagramphoenix, @nextreadbuddies, @bookishfriendsunite, @bookstafriendsengage, and @bipoc_readers.
image.caption:
Thank you @pnwxbibliophile for your thoughtful surprise as a random gift of kindness. This will be perfect for Indigenous Heritage Month and the Middle Grade prompt for @_indigathon. This book series is a great way to spark some conversations about the real significance of The Trail of Tears and learn some Indigenous History. Please head over to @_indigathon for more Indigenous content, education and to find awesome creators. If you're interested in #RAOK head over to the post by @travelling.the.pages so you can bless a bookstagram friend.

 🐍🐍🐍SYNOPSIS🐍🐍🐍

As Book 2 in Tim Tingle's award-winning How I Became A Ghost Series begins, his family continues the long walk to Indian Territory, and ten-year-old Isaac, our narrator and now a ghost, meets the famed Choctaw Chief and U.S. Army General Pushmataha. There have been surprises aplenty on the Trail thus far, but this one tops them all or so he thinks, until Isaac and his three Choctaw comrades learn they can now also time travel. With Pushmataha as their guide, Isaac and friends head back in time to the Washington,D.C., of 1824 to bear witness for the Choctaw chief who has come to the nation s capital at the invitation of his dear friend Andrew Jackson. You cannot blame the people before you for mistakes their ancestors made, Chief Pushmataha tells the little band, making a powerful and timeless lesson one made more so as the reader travels from graveyards to boarding schools, from 1824 to 2018, experiencing firsthand the joy of never leaving.

Cherokee Indians remained here, in the vast wilderness of their homeland, to avoid being forcibly moved by President Andrew Jackson to lands west of the Mississippi in the 1830s, a journey known as the Trail of Tears. The Cherokee had a word for this hiding place: Iyentooga, from which Heintooga took its name.

Although the land is now part of the national park, Richard Sneed, principal chief of the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians, says the mountains protected and provided for his people for many years. “Our hearts are connected to this place,” he says. #trailoftears #cherokeenation #cherokee #northcarolina  #history #taketheroadlesstraveled #goingbackintime
